BE

The results of the regression between the US Dollar on the one hand and the
FTSE mining shares and the gold price on the other show a strong relationship
between a strengthening US Dollar and weakening FTSE mining shares. The
chart below (in the main document) shows the regression since 2014, but the
results are consistent over various time periods (2-year, 10-year, and 20-year).

BE

BE

Reading the chart: The US Dollar explains 60% of FTSE mining shares returns
The US Dollar explains more of the FTSE mining than it does for the gold price.

A coefficient of determination (R-squared) of 60% between the FTSE
mining index and the US Dollar means that 60% of the changes in the
FTSE mining shares can be explained by the US Dollar.

Interestingly the regression shows that the FTSE mining shares are
more US Dollar-dependent than is the gold price. A coefficient of
determination of 47% for gold is not negligible but it is less robust
than that of the FTSE mining shares.
Our takeaway:
The US Dollar recently gained momentum with rising expectations of an
interest rate hike by the Fed in June or July. Further supportive data releases in
the US, such as the unemployment rate and unemployment claims, out on
June 3 and June 9 respectively, could support the US Dollar momentum and
consequently drive the FTSE mining shares lower.

PM

CREDIT SUISSE BOSS FACES REVOLT Credit Suisse, the second-largest bank in Switzerland after UBS, is in open revolt just a year after Tidjane Thiam took over as chief executive and shifted the bank's focus to wealth management, Landon Thomas Jr. reports in DealBook.

PM

For decades, Credit Suisse was dominated both culturally and financially by a richly paid banking elite and these deal makers are now furious at Mr. Thiam. He has cut their pay and blamed them for the $6 billion in losses that the firm has had on his watch.

11:14 am
PM

They don't like Tidjane tell 'em the truth

PM

PM

It is no surprise that he has not bent to the complaints of bankers and traders in unprofitable businesses. "There needs to be a cultural change," he said in a television interview in March, in which he argued that bankers were pursuing risky trades to justify their high pay.

In turn, deal makers in London and New York, who have seen their bonuses cut by nearly 40 percent, have not hidden their dislike for him.

Several bankers, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, grumbled that Mr. Thiam had "lost the building." That's Wall Street's way of saying that he no longer commanded the respect of traders. Bankers also said that when Mr. Thiam has appeared on television in recent months, employees loudly vented their frustrations at the screen.

BE

Here's Citi.

BE

Re-iterate Buy/High Risk rating and price target

Friday’s announcement of a victory in ANDA litigation v Par and Watson removes the near-term uncertainty and gives security of Suboxone film cash flows until at least April 2017 (NPV £1.76) and possibly until 2024 (NPV £2.80).

The earliest possible launch of a generic is now April 2017

which is the expiry of Teva’s 30 month stay. For that to happen, the court case, starting in November 2016, will have to rule that Teva’s manufacturing process does not infringe the ‘514 patent, which describes the uniform distribution of active ingredient on large sheets of film, allowing consistency of dosing.

11:22 am
BE

Further Suboxone film ANDA challenges lie ahead

after Teva, Indivior will have to defend its IP against Alvogen (court case April 2017), Mylan and Sandoz (November 2017). The company will be asserting further process patents in the meantime.

2016 remains an important year for the pipeline

key events will be Phase 3 results for RBP-6000 (buprenorphine monthly depot) and Phase 2A results for alcohol use disorder (3Q16) plus safety data on RBP-7000 (risperidone monthly depot) in 4Q16.

Risk/reward profile still looks favourable

despite the share price move (greater than 35%) on Friday, we like the risk/reward based on our scenario analysis detailed in the report. At current levels, the stock trades on 11.6x 2017E earnings with an estimated 2017-2022 EPS growth of 17%, versus sector average 10%.

BE

And Deutsche.

BE

Target Price up to 280p. Reiterate Buy
Following a positive litigation ruling on Friday preventing the launch of
generics to Suboxone film until 2024, we have reviewed our modelling
assumptions and upgrade our Price Target to 280p from 200p, representing
19% upside. In the near term we expect positive Ph III data for Indivior’s
Suboxone film follow-on product, see the potential for a settlement with
generic Suboxone film filers (rather than a drawn out appeal process) and
expect the company to undertake M&A to diversify its pipeline away from
Suboxone, a move which we believe would be taken well by investors.
Launch of generics to Suboxone film delayed to 2024
We had previously assumed launch of generics to Suboxone film from 2018.
After Friday’s court ruling we have shifted this to 2024 and now assume
market share declines of c5% per year (from 59% in 2015) until 2024 with lost
share going to: 1) Indivior’s follow-on product monthly buprenorphine which
we assume garners a 20% share (unchanged); 2) Generic Suboxone tablets
which we now assume will be more competitive on price given many of these
are marketed by companies included in the Film litigation and thus had an
incentive to preserve market dynamics in case they had won. We also adjust
our COGS, R&D and SG&A assumptions which had allowed for generic
competition from 2018. These changes increase our outer-year EPS by 15-25c
and significantly increase Indivior’s near-term operating cash flow.

11:22 am
BE

Upcoming catalysts
1) Ph III data for monthly buprenorphine (RBP-6000) in 3Q16 which we expect
to be positive. We model peak (2025) sales of $700m at an 80% probability to
market contributing 50% to our 280p PT; 2) M&A activity now Indivior has
more certainty around its near-term cash flows; 3) Potential settlement with all
generic filers (our base case); 4) Progression of cocaine esterase to Ph III
(2H16); 4) Potential partnering of monthly risperidone (schizophrenia).
Valuation and risks
We derive our PT using DCF (9% WACC lowered from 10%, beta 1, ERP 5.5%,
RFR 3.5% and TGR 0.4%). Risks include: 1) Successful litigation appeal by
generic companies; 2) Pipeline failure; 3) Fine after completion of the ongoing
anti-trust investigation; 4) Greater than expected share loss/pricing pressure.

BE

PM

Amazon may be rapidly gaining traction in apparel in the US, but our survey work suggests less of a threat in Europe. We think this is more than just a timing issue and reflects important structural differences between the two apparel markets.

PM

Amazon appears to be gaining significant traction in the US apparel market... Recent work by our US colleagues (Brian Nowak and Kimberley Greenberger) suggests that Amazon is now the second largest player in the US apparel market, with 7% market share. Brian and Kimberly believe that its share is likely to increase to 19% by 2020. The recent FYQ1 reporting season in the US would seem to provide considerable support to this thesis.
…but our AlphaWise survey suggests less so in Europe... Our survey work in Europe, however, shows Amazon gaining far less traction in apparel on this side of the Atlantic. Whereas 20% of US consumers regularly buy clothes from Amazon, only 7% do so in the UK.

PM

Welcome to ML

11:30 am
PM

We are becoming a little more constructive on ASOS… Of the retailers we cover, we believe that Zalando would be the most threatened if Amazon begins to gain significant traction in apparel in Europe. ASOS would potentially be impacted too, and we maintain our Underweight rating, but we are, nevertheless, becoming marginally more constructive on the name as it continues to benefit from significant FX tailwinds and it becomes more geographically focussed. We are raising our price target on ASOS today, but continue to see it as significantly overvalued. Conversely we are lowing our price target on Zalando, though retain our Overweight rating on the name.
...but YNAP remains our top European online retail play. We believe YNAP's focus on high-end goods, and the supply restrictions on them, gives it considerable protection from competition, whether from Amazon or others.

omg smile

PM

1. Why has Rocket's stake in Global Fashion Group reduced from 23% to 18% as per the most recent LPV information? What is the impact from new management incentives and additional funding from the new co-investment vehicle?
2. Why is Rocket exiting Lazada and are the put\call options likely to be exercised?
3. Does Rocket now have excess capital? In the last 6 months funding requirements have fallen (Africa, Lazada sale) and net cash up to €1.3bn. Overall liquidity is over €2.4bn.
4. Why did Rocket create the co-investment vehicle and will it be capped around $800m? How does it impact the group's liquidity position?
5. What progress has Rocket made in buying back part of the convertible debt (up to €150m of €550m)?
6. Why did management not commit to guidance of investing €250m to €350m at the Holdco level to end 2016? Is opportunistic M&A on agenda?

PM

7. Is ~€1bn cash held at the op co level sufficient to bring the "Proven Winners" to cash flow break-even, ex Lazada? Can the overall portfolio break even by 2018?
8. Why has growth been a challenge for the Home and Living companies in the last 6 months? Home24 has replaced key management. Should we should expect an improvement from 2q 2016?
9. Is HelloFresh’s progress further suggesting strong retention & longevity? How is it developing in the US & what impact has the Jamie Oliver deal had in Europe?
10. How is Delivery Hero’s market share developing in Germany? How is profitability developing?
11. What impact has the deterioration of emerging market conditions and FX had on Rocket's operations in areas such as Brazil + Russia? Does reduced funding throw up opportunities? In particular, is there more colour on the performance of Linio and Jumia?
12. Rocket has committed to at least one company becoming private in the next 18 months. What are the benefits of external value crystallisations and what is Rocket's attitude to its broader portfolio?
13. In management’s view, did Rocket underestimate the level of competition in India at Jabong and in other sectors? Is India considered "different," or is it a lead indicator for other markets?
14. How can we assess the prospects for the new concept companies?

BE

The UK’s largest residential estate agency, Countrywide, is to launch an online service in the clearest sign yet that digital disruption has arrived in the home sales market.

Countrywide will on Monday introduce a fixed-fee, pared-back service similar to those offered by online start-ups and “hybrid” agencies.

The FTSE 250 company, which runs more than 50 high street estate agency brands, will also integrate a digital offering into its traditional service and extend its working hours, in response to customer demand.

The move follows an investment last week by Savills, the country’s largest listed property agency, in Yopa — a fixed-fee “hybrid” agency that launched in January — as part of a £16m funding round.

A series of digital agencies such as eMoov, Purplebricks and easyProperty have opened since 2010, combining online technology with lower prices; most offer fixed fees in contrast with the percentage-based charges of traditional agents.

Countrywide PLC (CWD:LSE): Last: 362.50, down 7.5 (-2.03%), High: 370.00, Low: 356.90, Volume: 64.14k
BE

....... which allows me to drag out of the archive one of the best bits of research I've read for a month or two.

11:37 am
BE

A good, hard look at PurpleBricks' model from Jefferies.

BE

Who find that it's great for selling houses, unless you actually want to sell your house.

PM

eh?

11:38 am
BE

A great many, if not most, of the fixed-fee deals seem to collapse pre completion.

BE

Because PurpleBricks pays its agents for instructions, not for completions.

BE

Analysts here are Anthony Codling and Sam Cullen.

11:39 am
BE

Whether people buy or sell their homes through Purplebricks, we don't
recommend that they buy shares in the company. The numbers in the business
model look very attractive, however it is our view that they don’t add up. The
model appears to reward listings over sales, but we believe that sales rather
than listings will underpin the value of the shares and that costs will need to
increase in order to increase sales. Our 94p PT suggests significant downside.
The business model is attractive. Purplebricks (PB) must be applauded for reinventing
and recasting the economics of the franchise model in the franchisor's favour, and for that
alone the founding brothers Michael and Kenny deserve a Brucie bonus. The model, in
spreadsheet form, resembles a £50 note printing press.
But is it too good to be true? If it works in practice, it is compelling. But we have our
doubts. In our view, the model as it stands encourages sub-optimal behavior. Our analysis
suggests that each Local Property Expert (LPE) needs to win as many instructions per week
as a typical estate agency branch in order for PB to meet consensus estimates. With no
reward for actually selling a home, all eyes are focused on winning instructions, especially
if LPEs want to get close to the advertised OTE. We believe that, over time, PB's cost and
reward structures will need to change in order to both attract and retain the number of LPEs underpinning current consensus estimates.

BE

Finding a buyer is easy. PB claims that 'on average it takes us just 14 days to find a buyer',
which we agree is very impressive.
But closing a sale is 10 times harder. PB is silent on how long it actually takes to
complete the sale of your home. Our analysis of three of PB's more mature markets suggests
it takes on average 150 days, or five months, to sell a home, around 10 times longer than it
takes to find a buyer. Perhaps PB would be a more disruptive force if LPEs were also rewarded for the completion of a sale; this may also speed up the sale process and enhance PB's customer proposition.

BE

Long note. Let me fillet out another couple of paragraphs.

11:40 am
BE

Low fees, but also low sales rates. Across these three more mature markets, we also
analysed all the homes that, according to PB’s website, have been sold. We found that
only 5% of these sales have actually been recorded in the Land Registry database, and no
home that has been listed since 1 January 2016 has yet been legally sold. We appreciate
that it takes time for legal sales to be reported and recorded in the Land Registry database,
and our results may therefore paint a conservative picture. However, even if the sales rates
were double at 10%, we are not sure that many people would view PB’s offering as
compelling.

PM

Think posting this in the LR might be appreciated...

BE

Thousands of happy customers. PB advertises itself as ‘The estate agent with 5 star
local property experts and 1,000s of happy customers’ and quotes the number of 5-star
Trustpilot reviews. We were surprised at the level of 5-star reviews (86.6% from more than
5,000 reviews) given our analysis suggests that PB has not been able to complete the sale
of most of their customers’ homes. We suspect that reviews are sought around the
instruction and/or offer stage, rather than legal completion. There is nothing wrong in
this, although perhaps it points to where PB believes its value add lies: marketing homes
rather than selling them. The majority of the 2-star reviews (c.2% of all reviews) reflected
that service levels from PB fell significantly once an offer had been made and that some
had issues with PB’s conveyancing services. We also note that some reviews that were
‘under review’ have been removed from the Trustpilot site.

11:51 am
PM

They think it’s all over …by June 10: The Bundesliga has said its auction for the live rights for 2017/18 to 2020/21 will be complete by June 10. So far there has been little press commentary on the auction process. What we think Sky will buy: There are five Bundesliga broadcast live rights packages. We think Sky will aim to take four. If it wins all five, a new OTT package (which Sky wouldn’t be able to own) would be created, offering 102 out of the 306 games. We expect Sky to end up as the leading rights buyer but leaving an alternative bidder (maybe DT) owning the fifth package.

PM

How much we think Sky will pay: Last time Sky paid an average of €486m pa for all of the Bundesliga live rights. This time we expect Sky to pay 60% more at €780m pa for fewer rights. We think Sky will be unworried by the loss of a single package. The key is that it remains the dominant location for football fans. It also has the rights to the Champions League in Germany (where it pays €60m pa and the next auction is due in December). Even at €780m pa the Bundesliga rights would look well valued in the context of other markets (France €727m pa, Spain €883m, UK €2.2bn).

PM

What could go right for Sky? The key target for Sky is to obtain the bulk of the rights. The second target is to pay close to our €780m pa. The top end of the market range is €950m pa. Sky’s management observes that our figure of a €300m pa increase is equivalent to just 2% of the Sky cost base. The Sky share price performed well post the 2015 EPL renewal , even after an 83% increase in the rights cost, as uncertainty was removed. What could go wrong for Sky? We think SkyD is unusually dependent on football and estimate that the loss of the bulk of the Bundesliga rights would lead to a decline of one-third of SkyD customers (c1.5m). Our bear case forecasts are that SkyD EBITDA drops from a peak of £175m (€227m) in FY 17 to c£5-45m pa 2019-21e (€7m -€59m). At the EBITA level Sky D would remain loss-making through 2019-21e. Sky might on such a basis require a writedown on its c£4.6bn purchase price of SkyD in 2014. 50% off our SoP of €5bn for SkyD would be the equivalent of 117p per share off the valuation of Sky Group (or 10% of our SoP valuation).

11:52 am
PM

Relief awaited: We expect 2016/17 to be a down year of EPS (MS 59p) as Sky absorbs the £632m pa inflation in the EPL costs. At 933p the stock trades at 17x calendarised 2016 eps and 16.1x 2017 with a FCF yield of 6.8% and 7.1%. The shares have underperformed and getting the Bundesliga auction out of the way may mean some bounce in the shares .

PM

11:59 am
BE

Carnival will grow gross supply at a CAGR of 4.4% from 2016-2020 and 3.5% to 4%
net of ship dispositions/retirements. The mature markets, North America and Europe
will grow anywhere from 0% to 2% or 3%, while Asia as a whole (Japan, Hong Kong,
Singapore, Malaysia, Korea, China etc.) will grow in the high teens.
Yields in China are higher than the corporate average and there is continued
opportunity to improve margins and yields as Carnival increases scale efficiencies
and the consumer gets more educated. With few repeat customers, Carnival markets
mainly to first timers. As the industry gains penetration, the combination of critical
mass and more efficient marketing should increase both yield and margin.
Management sees the evolution of the distribution channel in China as a positive;
charters continue to demand inventory for future business. Currently, Carnival works
with 250-300 different agencies/groups selling cruises out of 2,600 that are licensed to
sell outbound travel; the expansion of their distribution system is a positive as the
industry grows. Today, charters are buying more groups and blocks of cabins from the
cruise lines versus full ships, which management prefers as it spreads the risk.

BE

Management remains optimistic that Cuba could be a port of call for their other
brands in the near future. The company recently launched sailings to Cuba as part of
Fathom, its social impact brand, on the 700 passenger Adonia and plans to expand
sailings on its other brands. While there remain political and logistical hurdles,
management believes they could add Cuba to Caribbean itineraries by 2017.

BE

CCL remains focused on optimizing revenues and costs. From 2014-year end 2016,
Carnival will have achieved $170mn in cost savings, which could more than double over the
next five years. On the revenue side, six brands will have 30% of their inventory on the
revenue yield optimizing system by year end with 100% of the inventory on the system by
2018.
Management remains focused on achieving double-digit ROIC within the next 2-3 years.
A 10% ROIC implies EPS in the low $4.00’s (our 2017E EPS is $3.85). Return of capital to
shareholders continues to be a priority.

...reflecting important structural differences in the markets. We do not believe that this is purely a timing issue – Amazon already accounts for c.4% of retail sales in the UK and Germany (vs 4.1% in the US). Rather, we think it reflects important structural differences between the European and US apparel markets, with department stores and off-pricers (and thus branded product) much more important in the US, but Europe dominated by 'vertically integrated' retailers (such as Zara and H&M), which sell only their own designs. However, 'Prime' subscriber growth has been increasing in the UK and Germany, which will need to be monitored given Prime subscribers' propensity to spend more on apparel.
